guide.introduction: In a survival situation, a small backpack that can transform to different uses besides simply carrying items will help your odds of survival. Here are instructions for making a lightweight and durable multi-use survival bag.
guide.introduction_rendered:
In a survival situation, a small backpack that can transform to different uses besides simply carrying items will help your odds of survival. Here are instructions for making a lightweight and durable multi-use survival bag.

Relevant parts
  • Emergency blanket
  • Tarpaulin lining
  • Velcro Strip
  • Rope
  • Towels
  • Plastic drop cloth
  • Backpack straps
  • Duct tape
Tools
  • Binder clips
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine
  • Tape measure
  • X-Acto knife

lines.text: Collect all required materials.
lines.text_raw: Collect all required materials.

lines.text: Lay out all the material and lay the cotton towels with the edges overlapping to form the shape of the tarpaulin layer.
lines.text_raw: Lay out all the material and lay the cotton towels with the edges overlapping to form the shape of the tarpaulin layer.

lines.text: Sew the edges of the towels together to form one large cotton sheet.
lines.text_raw: Sew the edges of the towels together to form one large cotton sheet.

lines.text: Lay out the tarpaulin lining and draw a 5.5 foot diameter circle.
lines.text_raw: Lay out the tarpaulin lining and draw a 5.5 foot diameter circle.

lines.text: You can cut a 2.25 ft length of rope, pin one end to the center of the fabric, and then create a 5.5 ft diameter circle.
lines.text_raw: You can cut a 2.25 ft length of rope, pin one end to the center of the fabric, and then create a 5.5 ft diameter circle.

lines.text: Cut the circle out of the material.
lines.text_raw: Cut the circle out of the material.

lines.text: Using the tarpaulin as a blueprint, draw similar circles on the cotton, emergency blanket, and plastic liner layers.
lines.text_raw: Using the tarpaulin as a blueprint, draw similar circles on the cotton, emergency blanket, and plastic liner layers.

lines.text: Lay the fabric in this order from bottom to top: tarpaulin, cotton, emergency blanket, and plastic liner.
lines.text_raw: Lay the fabric in this order from bottom to top: tarpaulin, cotton, emergency blanket, and plastic liner.

lines.text: Line up the layers then drop the rope on the edges.
lines.text_raw: Line up the layers then drop the rope on the edges.

lines.text: Roll the material over the rope and hold down the edge material with clips.
lines.text_raw: Roll the material over the rope and hold down the edge material with clips.

lines.text: Carefully stitch the inner portion of the folded edge using a sewing machine.
lines.text_raw: Carefully stitch the inner portion of the folded edge using a sewing machine.

lines.text: Ensure that you leave a space where the rope loops out of the fold.
lines.text_raw: Ensure that you leave a space where the rope loops out of the fold.

lines.text: Flip the material over with the tarpaulin liner on top.
lines.text_raw: Flip the material over with the tarpaulin liner on top.

lines.text: Find the center of the circle and draw a 9 inch radius circle about this point.
lines.text_raw: Find the center of the circle and draw a 9 inch radius circle about this point.

lines.text: Lay the velcro on this circle and hold it down with duct tape.
lines.text_raw: Lay the velcro on this circle and hold it down with duct tape.

lines.text: Sew the inner and outer edges of the velcro (i.e., inner and outer edges of the velcro circle).  Ensure that stitching is through all the layers.
lines.text_raw: Sew the inner and outer edges of the velcro (i.e., inner and outer edges of the velcro circle).  Ensure that stitching is through all the layers.

lines.text: Cut 8 strips 6 inches in length from the backpack strap material.
lines.text_raw: Cut 8 strips 6 inches in length from the backpack strap material.

lines.text: Approximately a foot from the edge of the circle, sew one of the strips in a loop fashion onto the fabric.
lines.text_raw: Approximately a foot from the edge of the circle, sew one of the strips in a loop fashion onto the fabric.

lines.text: Repeat the process above for 7 more loops and maintain an equal distance between loops (approximately 6.5 inches on the outer diameter of a circle with a foot smaller diameter than the larger circle).
lines.text_raw: Repeat the process above for 7 more loops and maintain an equal distance between loops (approximately 6.5 inches on the outer diameter of a circle with a foot smaller diameter than the larger circle).

lines.text: Cut 2 strips 4 feet in length from the backpack strap material.
lines.text_raw: Cut 2 strips 4 feet in length from the backpack strap material.

lines.text: Loop the cut strap through one of the loops and then sew the ends together.
lines.text_raw: Loop the cut strap through one of the loops and then sew the ends together.

lines.text: Repeat the process above using a loop adjacent to the one previously used.
lines.text_raw: Repeat the process above using a loop adjacent to the one previously used.

lines.text: Using the knife, cut small holes every 2 feet on the outer edge of the folded edges.
lines.text_raw: Using the knife, cut small holes every 2 feet on the outer edge of the folded edges.

lines.text: Use these holes to pull the rope through and scrunch the material to create a bag-like appearance.   This will require some strength and time.
lines.text_raw: Use these holes to pull the rope through and scrunch the material to create a bag-like appearance.   This will require some strength and time.

lines.text: Using the materials listed in this guide, the bag will stay slightly open.
lines.text_raw: Using the materials listed in this guide, the bag will stay slightly open.

lines.text: Cut another 10 foot length of rope.  Thread this section of rope through all the loops.
lines.text_raw: Cut another 10 foot length of rope.  Thread this section of rope through all the loops.

lines.text: Tighten the rope once it is through all the loops.
lines.text_raw: Tighten the rope once it is through all the loops.

lines.text: This should create a closed bag.
lines.text_raw: This should create a closed bag.

lines.text: The survival bag has multiple uses, the first of which is an actual back pack.
lines.text_raw: The survival bag has multiple uses, the first of which is an actual back pack.

lines.text: If the ropes are cut, the bag can open up and become a blanket or sleeping bag.
lines.text_raw: If the ropes are cut, the bag can open up and become a blanket or sleeping bag.

lines.text: Utilizing the existing straps and rope, a makeshift shelter can be built by tying the ends to objects in the environment.  The layers reflect back body heat and also have insulating properties, and this will provide a very lightweight and durable shelter.
lines.text_raw: Utilizing the existing straps and rope, a makeshift shelter can be built by tying the ends to objects in the environment.  The layers reflect back body heat and also have insulating properties, and this will provide a very lightweight and durable shelter.

lines.text: Flipped over, the reflective material can be used as a long-distance solar signal.
lines.text_raw: Flipped over, the reflective material can be used as a long-distance solar signal.

lines.text: If a hole is cut along the inner velcro circle, a person can place their head through it and a warm waterproof poncho is created.
lines.text_raw: If a hole is cut along the inner velcro circle, a person can place their head through it and a warm waterproof poncho is created.
